III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Policy and procedures
Title
1

Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12503
Section • (2) The policies and procedures must cover at least all the
Description following areas:
• (f) Amount of financial support and how it is
disbursed. An agency may not withhold financial
support intended for the youth while the youth is
actively involved in the program.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth's check is being withheld by staff at his IL placement.
Around 3/25/24, staff thought youth was in possession of a
marijuana pen, but it belonged to another youth. Youth was told
that the check was withheld due to positive drugs screen results
and not completing required services. Youth does not have food
at this time or money to purchase food due to their check being
withheld.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Foster Care Supervisor was interviewed via Microsoft Teams on
3/27/2024. She reported receiving drug screen results from Youth
A’s substance abuse counselor on 3/25/2024. She stated these
results showed a pattern of decreasing use followed by an
increase. She stated positive drug screens are a violation of his
probation as well as his independent living contract. She reported
there was a marijuana vape found in Youth A’s room, which also a
violation of his contract and program rules. Foster Care
Supervisor stated another youth originally told program staff
members he dropped the vape in Youth A’s room; however, that
youth later admitted he lied so Youth A wouldn’t get in trouble.
Foster Care Supervisor reported Youth A made statements to the
ILP home staff last week about no longer needing to participate in
any programming because he is turning 18 soon. Foster Care
Supervisor reported Youth A refused to participate in Life Skills
education last Thursday, 3/21/2024. She stated he was told on
3/27/2024 his stipend check, which was scheduled to arrive that
day, would be held due his continued engagement in criminality
(possession of the marijuana vape and violation of his probation,)
positive drug screens, and refusal to participate in life skills
education. She stated he was told if his recent drug screens came
back negative and he participated in Life Skills Education this
week, he would be given his check.
Foster Care Supervisor stated Foster Care Worker 1 met with
Youth A to discuss his food and other needs due to his check
being held. Foster Care Supervisor was told Youth A stated he
had food, and he didn’t have any needs. Foster Care Supervisor
2

stated Youth A was provided information about local food banks
and has access to community pantry items available to all the
youth in the home, such as peanut butter, canned goods, boxed
meals, etc.
Foster Care worker 1 was interviewed by phone on 3/27/2024.
She reported Youth A’s stipend check is being held because he
has been consistently testing positive for marijuana over the past
3 months. Additionally, on 3/13/24 he refused to participate in the
group portion of his independent living skills training which
equated 3 hours. Foster Care Worker 1 spoke with Foster Care
Supervisor, and they agreed if his most recent drug screen comes
back negative and he has a plan to make up his missing
independent living skills hours, they will release his check.
Foster Care Worker 1 reported phone numbers for local food
pantries are posted in the ILP home and there is some food in the
home any of the youth can access. She stated there are cameras
in the home and she sees Youth A eating all the time so there is
no concern that he doesn’t have food. She reported she is
currently working on a safety plan for him to ensure all his needs
are met while the check is being held.
Foster Care worker 2 was interviewed by phone on 3/27/2024.
She reported she met with Youth A on 3/25/2024. She stated he
had been angry earlier in the day when he found out his check
was being held, but he was calmed down by the time she met with
him. She stated he admitted the weed vape found in his room was
his and stated he knew his drug tests were positive.
Foster Care Worker 2 stated Foster Care Supervisor had offered
to order food from Wal-Mart to be delivered to the home, but he
told Foster Care Worker 2 he didn’t need it because he had
someone who would “hook him up.” She stated she gave him
information on local food banks as well. She offered a grocery
delivery a second time and he again declined.
Youth A was interviewed by phone on 3/27/2024. He reported he
made this complaint because he spent his last check on a phone
and already spent all his food stamps, so he didn’t know how was
going to get food when he was told his stipend check was being
withheld. He stated the check was being held because the staff of
the ILP home found a weed pen in his room, he tested positive for
marijuana, and he refused to participate in life skills training. He
stated he got another youth in the home to tell the staff the weed
pen was that youth’s, but the staff told Youth A they were
3

withholding his check anyway. When asked if the weed pen was
the other youth’s, Youth A said the staff, and everyone already
knew it was Youth A’s. Youth A stated he did test positive for
marijuana and had another test coming up Friday.
Youth A stated he did not refuse to participate in Life Skills
Training. He stated he was the only youth in the home
participating on the 13th. He stated he went upstairs to get ready
to go to the park for the remainder of the training and when the
trainer came upstairs to get him Youth A was sitting in a chair, put
his arm back and sighed because he really didn’t want to go. The
life skills trainer got mad and left the home.
Youth A stated Foster Care Supervisor called the house manager
on 3/25/2024 to find out if Youth A had food and to tell the staff to
give Youth A contact information to food pantries. Youth A stated
he told Foster Care Supervisor and Foster Care Worker 2 he
didn’t have any food. He denied anyone offering to order groceries
for him and stated he was only given food pantry information, but
he was not going to do that. He stated his mentor’s daughter is
going to help him out on Friday and he will figure something out
until then.
Youth A stated his biggest concern is he was told he would be
given his check if he tested negative for marijuana and if he made
up his life skills hours, but his life skills coach told him he couldn’t
make up those hours.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
Samaritas Procedure for Holding ILP Youth Stipend Checks due
to Noncompliance which states:
• Receiving stipend checks is contingent on youth continuing
to follow their IL agreement (DHHS 4527) and remaining in
compliance with the ILP program rules.
• When youth break ILP program rules, they will be informed
that their check will be held until they are back in
alignments with program expectations. Youth’s case
manager will meet with them to develop a safety plan to
rectify all compliance issues. This safety plan will include
details on how youth’s food, shelter, and basic needs will
be met without the funds from their stipend check.
Compliance Expectation Form signed by Youth A 7/18/2023
stating:
• Youth must complete 4 hours of life skills with a good
attitude each week.
4

• If there is a non-compliance, youth checks will be held until
completed.
Independent Living Agreements signed by Youth A on 7/18/2023,
9/26/2023, 11/13/2023, and 1/4/2024, all of which state:
• For the youth to continue to receive benefits, the youth
must:
• Obey the law.
• Actively engage in life skills training at least 4 hours per
week.
• Follow ILP house rules and compliance expectations.
Letter from Youth A addresses to “Samaritas” dated 3/25/2024 in
which Youth A apologized for not being compliant and disrupting a
meeting. He also stated he would like to make up his independent
living skills training hours and will stop using marijuana.
Independent Living Skills Activity Notes from 3/13/2024 which
documents Youth A was disengaged and did not actively
participate.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as, at the time Youth A’s
stipend check was withheld he was not complying with program
expectations and independent living agreements he had signed
and agreed to follow; therefore, he was not actively engaged in
the program.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.

sir_summary.summary: A youth's financial stipend was withheld by Samaritas staff due to alleged program violations including positive drug tests, possession of a marijuana vape, and refusal to participate in life skills training. The investigation concluded the agency was in compliance, as withholding was allowed per the youth's signed agreements when not actively engaged in the program, and staff offered food assistance alternatives. No substantial violations were found, so no culpability is assigned to the facility.
